questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency room with severe substernal chest pain, diaphoresis, and nausea. Imaging reveals transmural myocardial infarction in the posterior one-third of the interventricular septum. The infarcted region is normally supplied by which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
The posterior one-third of the interventricular septum is supplied by the posterior descending artery (PDA), which most commonly branches off from the right coronary artery (RCA).

The network of blood vessels supplying the heart itself is termed the coronary circulation. The different arteries in the coronary circulation and the regions supplied by each are summarized below:  




Option Analysis

❌ Left circumflex artery  :
Incorrect: The left circumflex artery usually supplies the lateral and posterior walls of the left ventricle.  
❌ Left anterior descending artery  :
Incorrect: The left anterior descending artery normally supplies the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum (septal branches), anterior wall of the left ventricle, and parts of the anterior papillary muscle.  
✅ Posterior descending artery  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Right marginal artery  :
Incorrect: The right marginal artery supplies the right ventricle.  
❌ Left marginal artery  :
Incorrect: The left marginal artery supplies the left ventricle.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department because of episodic, burning substernal chest pain. According to past medical records, the patient has a right-dominant circulation. A myocardial perfusion scan reveals inducible ischemia in the posteroinferior surface of the heart. This region of the heart is supplied by which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
Coronary dominance is determined by the coronary artery that supplies the posterior descending artery (PDA). The PDA originates from one of the following:

1) Right coronary artery in approximately 70-80% of the population (right dominant)
2) Left circumflex artery in approximately 5-10% of the population (left dominant)
3) Both right coronary and left circumflex arteries in 10-20% of the population (codominant)

The posterior descending artery runs along the posterior interventricular groove and supplies the posterior one-third of the interventricular septum, as well as the posterior two-thirds of the ventricles.

In this patient with right dominant circulation, occlusion of the right coronary artery would account for the inducible ischemia in the posteroinferior surface of the heart.  



Option Analysis

❌ Left circumflex artery  :
Incorrect: The left circumflex artery usually supplies the lateral and posterior walls of the left ventricle.  
❌ Left anterior descending artery  :
Incorrect: The left anterior descending artery normally supplies the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum (septal branches), anterior wall of the left ventricle, and parts of the anterior papillary muscle.  
❌ Obtuse marginal artery  :
Incorrect: The obtuse marginal artery is a branch of the left circumflex artery and supplies the lateral wall of the left ventricle.  
❌ Left main coronary artery  :
Incorrect: In the approximately 10% of individuals who have left dominant circulation, the posterior descending artery branches from the circumflex branch of the left main coronary artery. However, this patient has right dominant circulation.  
✅ Right main coronary artery  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department to be evaluated for retrosternal chest pain. The pain started four hours ago while playing soccer with his grandchild. The pain radiates to his left arm and jaw and is not associated with breathing or position changes. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Cardiac catheterization is performed via the femoral artery and demonstrates stenosis of the following arteries: 70% left main coronary artery, 90% proximal left anterior descending artery, and 80% right coronary artery. Six hours following catheterization, the patient states that he is experiencing generalized weakness and back pain. Temperature is 37.1℃ (98.8℉), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 96/60 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates cold and clammy extremities. A 5 cm area of ecchymosis is noted surrounding the femoral puncture site. Palpation and auscultation of catheter access sites are unremarkable. The patient has palpable, thready dorsalis pedis pulses bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of sudden onset back pain, generalized weakness, and hypotension with cold and clammy extremities after cardiac catheterization is consistent with retroperitoneal hemorrhage. This patient’s condition likely occurred secondary to accidental puncture of the posterior wall of the common femoral artery.   

The common femoral artery serves as the continuation of the external iliac artery as it crosses the inguinal ligament and is often used as a site for vascular access. Retroperitoneal bleeding is frequently related to artery puncture above the inguinal ligament, as this portion of the vessel lies directly inferior to the peritoneum. Accidental puncture of the posterior wall of the common femoral artery can cause blood to track along the vascular fascial sheath into the retroperitoneum or rectus sheath.  

Due to the size of the retroperitoneal space, significant hemorrhage can occur before the development of any clinical signs or symptoms. Back pain, hypotension, and a significant drop in hemoglobin after a procedure are signs of a retroperitoneal hemorrhage. Diagnosis is confirmed via computed tomography imaging.  

Option Analysis

❌ Pseudoaneurysm:
Incorrect: A pseudoaneurysm is associated with clinical findings of pain at the access site combined with ecchymosis and subcutaneous hematoma. It is often recognized by the presence of a pulsatile mass with a systolic bruit overlying the catheter insertion site. This patient does not have symptoms or signs on physical examination of a pseudoaneurysm. Pseudoaneurysms do not typically lead to loss of a large volume of blood and hypotension. 
❌ Arteriovenous fistula:
Incorrect: Bleeding from the arterial puncture site may fistulize into the adjacent femoral vein. It may be recognized clinically by the presence of a thrill or continuous bruit. The time of symptom onset ranges from two days to several months after catheterization.
❌ Allergic reaction to iodinated contrast:
Incorrect: An allergic reaction to iodinated contrast typically presents with urticaria, pruritus, facial edema, as well as transient warmth or chills. Allergic reactions usually occur within twenty minutes of exposure. Anaphylaxis from contrast media occurs within minutes of exposure.
✅ Retroperitoneal hemorrhage:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Arterial thrombosis:
Incorrect: Patients with lower extremity arterial thrombosis present with pain or paresthesias in the affected leg, as well as reduced or absent distal pulses.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to 20 minutes of crushing chest pain and diaphoresis that began suddenly while watching television. According to the patient’s partner, lately he has had occasional chest pain occurring during rest that resolved after a few minutes. Medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus. The patient has not been compliant with the medications. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6° F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. The patient appears to be in acute distress and in pain. Cardiac examination shows an additional sound just prior to S1 on auscultation. ECG demonstrates ST segment elevation in leads V1-V5. While being prepared for percutaneous coronary intervention, the patient suddenly dies. Following this patient’s death, an autopsy is performed to better understand the underlying pathology. At the time of this patient's death, which of the following sets of findings is most likely to be seen in the anterior wall of the myocardium?

choices.text: Gross changes Microscopic changes Red gray infarct  Extensive phagocytosis and granulation tissue
Gross changes Microscopic changes  Mottling with a yellow-tan center Coagulative necrosis and acute inflammation with neutrophils
Gross changes Microscopic changes Hyperemic border with a yellow-tan centerMyofiber disintegration and acute inflammation with macrophages
Gross changes Microscopic changes Dark mottling Coagulation necrosis and contraction bands
Gross changes Microscopic changes None  No changes and/or presence of wavy fibers
Gross changes Microscopic changes Grey-white to white color  Dense collagen

questions.solution:
This patient suffered an acute myocardial infarction (MI) complicated by ventricular arrhythmia and sudden cardiac death. Up to four hours after a MI, no changes are expected on gross morphology, while microscopic appearance varies from no changes seen to the presence of wavy fibers. The wavy appearance reflects the stretching and buckling of noncontractile dead fibers.  

The following chart summarizes the gross morphologic changes, microscopic changes, and possible complications based on the time since MI:  



Option Analysis

❌  Gross changes Microscopic changes Red gray infarct  Extensive phagocytosis and granulation tissue :
Incorrect: These changes are expected 7-14 days after myocardial infarction.
❌  Gross changes Microscopic changes  Mottling with a yellow-tan center Coagulative necrosis and acute inflammation with neutrophils:
Incorrect: These changes are expected 1-3 days after myocardial infarction. 
❌  Gross changes Microscopic changes Hyperemic border with a yellow-tan centerMyofiber disintegration and acute inflammation with macrophages:
Incorrect: These changes are expected 3-7 days after myocardial infarction. 
❌  Gross changes Microscopic changes Dark mottling Coagulation necrosis and contraction bands:
Incorrect: These changes can be seen 4-24 hours after myocardial infarction. Ongoing coagulation necrosis will result in pyknosis of the nuclei (condensation of chromatin) and hypereosinophilic appearance of myocytes, due to contraction band formation. Contraction bands are a unique finding for cardiac myocytes; they are thought to arise from reperfusion and hypercontraction, which results in sarcolemmal rupture leading to free calcium influx. 
✅  Gross changes Microscopic changes None  No changes and/or presence of wavy fibers:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Gross changes Microscopic changes Grey-white to white color  Dense collagen  :
Incorrect: The formation of a fibrous scar consisting of dense collagen begins after two weeks and is completed within several months after myocardial infarction.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male college student suddenly collapses and dies while playing in a football game. His teammate reports that the patient mentioned “feeling off” just before the game started but attributed it to being nervous for the game. Medical history is noncontributory, and the parents report that he was completely healthy and took no medications. According to friends, the patient drank approximately 2-3 beers on weekends and did not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death in this patient?
questions.solution:
This previously healthy young athlete died from sudden cardiac death (SCD) [or sudden cardiac arrest (SCA)], which is most commonly due to a fatal ventricular tachyarrhythmia (e.g. ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation). SCD (or SCA) refers to the sudden cessation of cardiac activity along with hemodynamic collapse, which most commonly occurs in the setting of an ongoing ventricular tachyarrhythmia. The majority of patients experience chest pain and/or dyspnea 1 hour prior to the event.  

Causes of SCD can be divided according to the etiology as follows: in adults over the age of 35, it is most often associated with coronary artery disease; however, in younger adults, other causes should be investigated, including cardiomyopathies and hereditary ion channelopathies. Risk factors for CAD overlap risk factors for SCD. These include hypertension, dyslipidemia, physical inactivity, cigarette smoking, obesity, diabetes mellitus, and a family history of premature CAD or myocardial infarction.    

Option Analysis

❌ Aortic dissection:
Incorrect: Aortic dissection presents with sudden-onset of tearing chest pain radiating to the back. Aortic dissection can be fatal; however, it is usually seen in patients with risk factors such as hypertension, bicuspid aortic valve, and inherited connective tissue disorders (e.g. Marfan syndrome).   
❌ Ventricular free wall rupture:
Incorrect: Ventricular free wall rupture is a possible complication seen after acute myocardial infarction (MI), and usually occurs within the first 2 weeks following the MI. This young patient has no known medical history or risk factors suggestive of coronary artery disease.   
❌ Pericarditis :
Incorrect: Pericarditis can be seen after myocardial infarction (MI) or viral illness, and is not a common cause of sudden cardiac death. Patients commonly present with sharp chest pain that is aggravated by inspiration and relieved by sitting up and leaning forward.   
❌ Atrial fibrillation:
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation is a common cause of arrhythmias; however, it is not a common cause of sudden cardiac death.   
✅ Ventricular tachyarrhythmia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to chest pain that started 12 hours ago while watching television. The patient describes the pain as “heavy pressure” located in the center of the chest that radiates up to the neck and jaw. He states that the pain has waxed and waned, although he has felt some relief from taking sublingual nitroglycerin. Medical history is significant for coronary artery disease, stable angina, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient’s temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 135/93 mmHg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Chest x-ray shows no abnormalities, cardiac enzymes are negative, and ECG shows ST-segment depression in the anterior leads. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with substernal chest pain at rest, which has not improved completely with nitroglycerin, on a background history of stable angina. This change in his usual chest pain, as well as his ECG findings and negative cardiac biomarkers, all favor the diagnosis of unstable angina.   

Unstable angina is defined as an increase in frequency or intensity of prior chest pain (stable angina) or any chest pain at rest, and it usually lasts more than 20 minutes. Unstable angina is usually related to atherosclerotic plaque rupture leading to incomplete occlusion of the coronary arteries. ECG findings typically include ST-depression and/or T-wave inversion, but cardiac biomarkers are negative. Although unstable angina and non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) are treated the same, they differ primarily based on whether the ischemia is severe enough to cause the irreversible cellular injury (infarction) which causes cardiac biomarker release from myocytes. If cardiac biomarkers were elevated, the diagnosis would be an NSTEMI, which is not seen in this case.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Diffuse esophageal spasm:
Incorrect: Diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) is a neuromuscular disorder in which non-peristaltic contractions of the esophagus cause chest pain. Patients typically complain of dysphagia, heartburn, and regurgitation. Manometry shows non-peristaltic, uncoordinated esophageal contractions, and barium swallow test shows a “corkscrew” pattern. Although DES also causes chest pain, it does not cause ECG changes, and this patient has no history of dysphagia.   
❌ Non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction  :
Incorrect: Both unstable angina and non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) are caused by atherosclerotic plaque rupture and present with ST-segment depression on ECG; however, unlike unstable angina, NSTEMI is associated with an increase in troponins and other cardiac enzymes. This patient had negative cardiac biomarkers.   
❌ Prinzmetal angina  :
Incorrect: Vasospastic angina (formerly “Prinzmetal angina”) is a clinical entity characterized by episodic chest pain attributable to coronary artery vasospasm, resulting in obstruction. These episodes are not related to increased myocardial oxygen demand, such as exertion. Instead, common triggers include use of alcohol, tobacco, cocaine and triptans. ECG typically shows ST-segment elevation with negative cardiac biomarkers. This patient has a history of stable angina and multiple coronary artery disease risk factors, favoring another diagnosis.  
❌ Stable angina:
Incorrect: Stable angina is ischemic chest pain that occurs with exertion and abates with rest or nitroglycerin. Unless an electrocardiogram (ECG) is done at the time of chest pain, there are very rarely ECG changes. Cardiac biomarkers are negative. This patient’s pain occurred at rest, and his pain did not abate with nitroglycerin, which favors another diagnosis.   
✅ Unstable angina:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to chest discomfort that started suddenly 20 minutes ago while he was trying to fall asleep. The patient describes the pain as a “squeezing” in the center of the chest that moves to the neck and jaw; there are no changes in pain with respiration or position. The patient has not had any recent travel, sick contacts, or illnesses. Medical history is significant for a 5-pack-year smoking history, and no alcohol or illicit drugs. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg. The patient appears to be in distress and is diaphoretic. Electrocardiogram shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads. The patient is given nitroglycerin and the pain resolves within a few minutes. Which of the following findings is most likely underlying pathophysiology responsible for this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Inflammation of the serosal lining membranes
Atherosclerotic plaque obstructing 80% of the coronary artery lumen without thrombus
Rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque with thrombus partially occluding the coronary artery lumen
Minimal atherosclerotic plaque and coronary artery spasm
Rupture of atherosclerotic plaque with thrombus fully occluding the coronary artery lumen

questions.solution:
This previously healthy young adult, with a significant smoking history and no additional risk factors for coronary artery disease, who presents with chest pain that began during rest, most likely has vasospastic angina (previously called Prinzmetal or variant angina). Vasospastic angina is a clinical entity characterized by episodic chest pain attributable to coronary artery vasospasm. The chest pain in vasospastic angina, similar to coronary artery disease, does not change with position or inspiration.  

Vasospastic angina is caused by spasm of the smooth muscle layer of the arterial wall of the coronary artery, resulting in a high-grade obstruction. Vascular smooth muscle hyperreactivity is believed to play a key role in the pathogenesis. Spasms can occur in angiographically normal coronary arteries but more often occur at the site of atherosclerotic plaques. Common triggers and risk factors include alcohol, smoking, cocaine and triptans. The diagnosis is made when patients present with recurrent episodes of typical anginal pain and are found to have transient ST-segment elevation on ECG/Holter monitor followed by insignificant findings of atherosclerosis at coronary arteriography. Treatment consists of nitrates, calcium channel blockers, and smoking cessation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Inflammation of the serosal lining membranes:
Incorrect: Inflammation of the serosal lining membranes of the heart can be seen in pericarditis, which can occur after myocardial infarction (MI) or viral illness. Patients often present with sharp chest pain that is aggravated by inspiration and relieved by sitting up and leaning forward. ECG will likely show widespread ST-segment elevation and/or PR depression. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Atherosclerotic plaque obstructing 80% of the coronary artery lumen without thrombus:
Incorrect: Atherosclerotic plaque obstructing 80% of the coronary artery lumen will likely cause symptoms of stable angina. These symptoms include exertional chest pain which is relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque with thrombus partially occluding the coronary artery lumen:
Incorrect: Rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque with thrombus partially occluding the coronary artery lumen can be seen in unstable angina or non–ST-segment elevation MI (NSTEMI). Electrocardiogram in patients with NSTEMI or unstable angina will likely show ST depression rather than ST-segment elevation. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.  
✅ Minimal atherosclerotic plaque and coronary artery spasm :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rupture of atherosclerotic plaque with thrombus fully occluding the coronary artery lumen:
Incorrect: Rupture of atherosclerotic plaque with thrombus fully occluding the coronary artery lumen can be seen in patients with ST-segment elevation MI (STEMI). Symptoms of STEMI are unlikely to resolve with nitroglycerin.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to an acute onset of epigastric pain. The pain started 30 minutes ago while she was gardening. She has been feeling nauseous and vomited once since the pain started. She denies chest pain or shortness of breath. Her medical history is significant for a 20-pack-year smoking history, hypertension, peptic ulcer disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and cholelithiasis. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg. The patient appears distressed and diaphoretic. Physical examination shows normal heart sounds with no murmurs or gallops on auscultation. Lung auscultation reveals normal breath. Abdominal examination shows a soft, nontender abdomen with normal bowel sounds. Which of the following investigations should be immediately performed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This female patient’s presentation with multiple coronary artery disease (CAD) risk factors (older age, smoking, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus) and acute onset of epigastric pain and vomiting prompts immediate cardiac evaluation, including an electrocardiogram (ECG) and cardiac biomarkers (e.g. troponins) in order to rule out acute coronary syndrome (ACS). This patient’s presentation highlights the fact that certain populations may have atypical presentations of ACS, including women, older patients, and patients with diabetes mellitus.   

The typical presentation of ACS includes “crushing” substernal chest pain that radiates to the shoulder, neck, and/or jaw, along with associated symptoms such as dyspnea and diaphoresis. As seen in this case, atypical presentations may include more subtle chest pain, epigastric pain, or no pain at all. These patients may present only with dyspnea, palpitations, nausea and/or vomiting, or syncope. These atypical presentations can delay prompt diagnosis and management, leading to worse outcomes. Therefore, one must have a high index of suspicion in patients with multiple CAD risk factors who present with vague symptoms. Other tests may be considered but are not urgent as ruling out ACS. Thus, the best initial test in all patients with chest pain and in high-risk patients is an ECG.   

Option Analysis

❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: A colonoscopy may be used to evaluate a number of gastrointestinal conditions including polyps, cancer, and diverticular disease. An urgent colonoscopy may be indicated in an older patient presenting with iron deficiency anemia or other evidence of gastrointestinal bleeding. This older female patient’s vague presentation of epigastric pain with multiple cardiac risk factors instead warrants urgent cardiovascular evaluation.   
❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: An abdominal ultrasound can help diagnose a number of abdominal and pelvic conditions such as cholelithiasis, acute cholecystitis and ovarian pathologies. This older female patient’s vague presentation of epigastric pain with multiple cardiac risk factors warrants urgent cardiovascular evaluation.   
❌ Serum amylase and lipase  :
Incorrect: Serum amylase and lipase can be obtained to support the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis. While the patient does have gallstones, which is a common cause of pancreatitis, this presentation is not consistent with acute pancreatitis. This older female patient’s vague presentation of epigastric pain with multiple cardiac risk factors instead warrants urgent cardiovascular evaluation.   
✅ Electrocardiogram:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ D-dimer:
Incorrect: D-dimer is used to exclude pulmonary embolism when there is low clinical suspicion. This older female patient’s vague presentation of epigastric pain with multiple cardiac risk factors instead warrants urgent cardiovascular evaluation.   
❌ Upright abdominal x-ray:
Incorrect: An upright abdominal x-ray can help evaluate for a bowel obstruction by visualizing dilated loops of bowel and air-fluid levels. This older female patient’s vague presentation of epigastric pain with multiple cardiac risk factors instead warrants urgent cardiovascular evaluation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to 20 minutes of crushing chest pain and diaphoresis that began suddenly while watching television. According to the patient’s partner, lately he has had occasional chest pain occurring during rest that resolved after a few minutes. Medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus. The patient has not been taking medications as prescribed. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6° F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. The patient appears to be in acute distress and in pain. Cardiac examination shows an additional sound just prior to S1 on auscultation. ECG demonstrates ST segment elevation in leads V1-V5. While being prepared for percutaneous coronary intervention, the patient suddenly dies. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has multiple cardiac risk factors (e.g. hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and a history of unstable angina) and is now presenting with acute onset of chest pain and diaphoresis. In addition, his ECG findings show ST-elevation in leads V1-V5, supporting the diagnosis of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) affecting the anterior wall (left anterior descending artery).  



Symptoms of MI may include severe retrosternal chest pain radiating to the left arm and/or jaw, diaphoresis, nausea, vomiting, shortness of breath, and fatigue. The additional heart sound S4 represents the stiffening of the wall during diastole, and although nonspecific, it is often correlated with an acute MI. Diagnosis involves measurement of cardiac biomarkers (e.g., troponins) and an ECG to look for ST changes and the presence of Q waves.   

Myocardial infarction can be complicated by a variety of conditions depending on the location of injury and timeline since the initial insult. During the first 24 hours, the most common cause of death is ventricular tachycardia/ventricular fibrillation leading to sudden cardiac death (SCD). SCD refers to a sudden stop of cardiac activity followed by hemodynamic collapse.  

Option Analysis

❌ Papillary muscle rupture:
Incorrect: Papillary muscle rupture is a possible life-threatening complication of acute myocardial infarction (MI), but it usually occurs after 2–7 days, not immediately after an MI. Papillary muscle dysfunction results in acute mitral regurgitation. The posteromedial papillary muscle receives its blood supply from the posterior descending artery and is the most commonly affected papillary muscle.   
✅ Ventricular arrhythmia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Free wall rupture:
Incorrect: Free wall rupture is a possible complication of MI that can lead to cardiac tamponade progressing to pulseless electrical activity and death. However, this complication usually occurs 5-14 days post MI.  
❌ Thromboembolic stroke:
Incorrect: Thromboembolic stroke can occur as a result of a mural thrombus following MI. Hypokinesis of the involved myocardium leads to blood stasis and thrombus formation. However, mural thrombi usually take a few days (average of 6 days) to develop and are not a cause of sudden cardiac death.   
❌ Interventricular septal rupture:
Incorrect: Interventricular septal rupture is a possible complication following MI. This complication can occur when the left anterior descending artery, which provides the main blood supply for the septum, is involved. Interventricular septal rupture occurs 3-5 days post infarction, not on the first day. Interventricular septal rupture leads to hemodynamic compromise, which is characterized by hypotension, biventricular failure, and a new harsh holosystolic murmur.  
❌ Fibrinous pericarditis  :
Incorrect: Fibrinous pericarditis, also known as Dressler Syndrome, is a late complication of MI seen several weeks post-MI. Dressler Syndrome is caused by an autoimmune reaction against cardiac antigens released during the cardiac injury.   
❌ Atrial fibrillation:
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation can occur in association with MI and is a predictor of poor outcome. The atrial fibrillation itself is not the cause of death. However, the associated symptoms, such as heart failure and cardiogenic shock, contribute to mortality. Sudden cardiac death post-MI is most frequently the result of a ventricular tachyarrhythmia, not atrial.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to chest pain that started suddenly 15 minutes ago while playing with his grandchildren. The patient describes the pain as “pressure and tightness” located in the center of his chest. The patient reports that he occasionally experiences mild chest discomfort when going up the stairs. Medical history is significant for a 30-pack-year smoking history, hypercholesterolemia, and hypertension. The patient is given a sublingual medication while in the emergency department, and the symptoms resolve within a few minutes. Which of the following sets of hemodynamic changes is most likely to be seen in this patient following the administration of this medication?  

*(-) decrease, (0) no effect, (+) increase
questions.solution:
This patient with multiple coronary artery disease (CAD) risk factors (smoking, hypercholesterolemia, hypertension), who now presents with substernal chest pain with exertion that resolves with nitroglycerin, most likely has stable angina. Stable angina most commonly occurs secondary to atherosclerosis. The onset of stable angina symptoms typically occurs when there is ≥70% coronary artery occlusion. Atherosclerosis leads to mismatch between oxygen demand and consumption, which becomes more pronounced during exertion.  

Nitrates (nitroglycerin) work by increasing nitric oxide (NO) release in vascular smooth muscle cells, which causes elevation of cGMP and smooth muscle relaxation. This process results in vasodilation of veins and arteries, leading to increased peripheral venous capacitance and decreased systemic vascular resistance (SVR), respectively. When blood pools in the venous system, less blood flows back to the heart (decreased preload), which reduces myocardial wall stress and oxygen consumption. This mechanism is believed to be responsible for the antianginal effects of nitrates. The reduction in SVR also decreases cardiac wall stress, since the heart has to overcome less resistance to pump blood out (decreased afterload). In addition, nitrates also mildly vasodilate the coronary arteries, leading to increased oxygen delivery to the myocardium. However, the vasodilation of arteries only has a minor contribution, because nitrates affect veins more than arteries. The heart rate is increased due to barorecptors induced reflex tachycardia in response to reduced blood pressure.  



Option Analysis

❌   Heart rate   Preload reduction  Afterload reduction  +  0  ++ :
Incorrect: Hydralazine is an antihypertensive medication that preferentially reduces afterload. The increased heart rate is due to reflex tachycardia in response to reduced blood pressure. The exact mechanism of action is unknown, but arterial dilation is thought to occur via blockage of calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum and inhibition of myosin phosphorylation in arterial smooth muscle cells.
✅   Heart rate   Preload reduction  Afterload reduction  + ++ + :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌   Heart rate   Preload reduction  Afterload reduction 0++ ++ :
Incorrect: Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEI, e.g. enalapril) is a class of antihypertensive medications that work by inhibiting the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, a potent vasoconstrictor. In addition, it reduces aldosterone secretion, which further reduces the blood pressure. ACEI reduces preload and afterload but has no effect on the heart rate. 
❌   Heart rate   Preload reduction  Afterload reduction  - 0  +:
Incorrect: Carvedilol is a beta-blocker class medication with a nonselective beta-adrenoreceptor and alpha-adrenergic blocking activity. As a result, there is a decrease in heart rate, cardiac output, and peripheral vascular resistance.  
❌   Heart rate   Preload reduction  Afterload reduction  0 0  ++ :
Incorrect: Dihydropyridines (e.g. amlodipine) are a type of calcium channel blockers that act on vascular smooth muscle. It works by blocking voltage-dependent L-type calcium channels of cardiac and smooth muscle, thereby reducing muscle contractility. Non-dihydropyridines (e.g. diltiazem) also work on the cardiac nodal tissue and reduce the heart rate.

questions.text:
An 85-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of chest discomfort and shortness of breath that started two hours ago while watching television. Past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. During the past 10 years, the patient has had similar episodes of chest pain, which resolved with rest. The patient’s pulse is 94/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 134/86 mmHg. The patient appears to be in distress and is diaphoretic. Physical examination shows normal heart sounds with no murmurs or gallops on auscultation. An ECG is obtained (see image below). Treatment is administered, and the patient suddenly reports feeling faint and loses consciousness. Which of the following medications is most likely the cause of the patient’s worsened condition?  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia commons
questions.solution:
Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) should be considered in any patient with chest discomfort, shortness of breath, or other suggestive symptoms, especially given this patient's risk factors of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient’s known history of similar pain episodes that resolve with rest (consistent with stable angina) raises clinical suspicion that these present symptoms, which have persisted despite rest, represent myocardial infarction (MI). The ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, confirming the diagnosis of ST-elevation MI (STEMI). The involvement of these inferior leads indicates an inferior wall infarction, involving the right coronary artery. The next best step is to obtain right-sides leads (mirror position) to assess possible infarction of the right ventricle.  

Since right ventricular function is highly preload-dependent, treatment with nitrates can further decrease right-sided cardiac output, leading to hypotension and cardiogenic shock. Other drugs that can negatively affect the preload (opioids) or cardiac contractility and heart rate (beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers) are also relatively contraindicated, particularly in patients who are hemodynamically unstable.  




Option Analysis

❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: All patients with suspected acute coronary syndrome should be given aspirin unless previously taken. Potential contraindications include a history of an anaphylactic reaction. The patient has no history of an anaphylactic reaction.   
❌ Clopidogrel:
Incorrect: Clopidogrel is a platelet P2Y12 receptor blocker that is used in acute myocardial infarction (AMI) together with aspirin. Hypotension is not a known complication of clopidogrel.   
❌ Warfarin:
Incorrect: Warfarin is an anticoagulant that inhibits epoxide reductase enzyme which impedes γ-carboxylation of vitamin K–dependent clotting factors and has no role in the treatment of AMI. Hypotension is not a side effect of warfarin.   
✅ Nitrates:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Dopamine:
Incorrect: Dopamine is an inotropic agent used during right ventricular MI when fluid resuscitation is insufficient. It causes vasoconstriction and elevation of blood pressure, not hypotension.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old woman comes to the hospital for evaluation of intermittent episodes of chest pain that started four months ago. The patient reports that the chest pain is triggered by physical activity and improves with rest. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 150/75 mmHg, pulse is 67/min, and BMI is 29 kg/m2. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are non-contributory. An ECG is performed and shown below. The patient is started on a medication for her chest pain and is counseled on its side effects, which include constipation, facial flushing, and gingival hyperplasia. This medication works via which of the following mechanisms of action?


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) are a class of vasodilators or medications that promote dilation of blood vessels. These medications are most commonly used to treat hypertension, supraventricular tachycardia, and angina pectoris (also called stable angina), pain caused by reduced blood flow to the heart muscle. Of note, this patient has chest pain that worsens with activity and improves with rest as well as a normal resting EKG, which is consistent with angina pectoris.    

As its name suggests, CCBs work by blocking voltage-gated calcium channels. This decreases the frequency with which calcium channels open, hence reducing calcium influx and intracellular calcium concentrations. In the sinoatrial node, CCBs are able to slow down cellular depolarization, which in turn decreases heart rate.    

Moreover, by reducing calcium influx, CCBs reduce calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, ultimately impairing muscle contractions. In the heart, this phenomenon causes decreased myocardial contractility as well as vasodilation of the coronary vessels.  

Ultimately, CCBs treat angina via two mechanisms: 1) decreasing the heart’s oxygen demand by reducing heart rate and contractility, and 2) increasing its oxygen supply via coronary artery vasodilation. Side effects of CCBs include peripheral edema, headaches, flushing, reflexive tachycardia, and gingival hyperplasia.  



Option Analysis

✅ Blockade of L-type calcium channels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Stimulation of intracellular guanylyl cyclase:
Incorrect: Medications such as nitrates promote vasodilation via this mechanism. The activated guanylyl cyclases increase cGMP concentration, which in turn causes dephosphorylation of myosin light chains. As a result, light chains are unable to interact with actin and vasodilation occurs. While nitrates can be used to treat angina, they would not typically cause gingival hyperplasia
❌ Blockade of voltage-gated sodium channels:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of class I antiarrhythmic drugs (e.g., quinidine, lidocaine, propafenone). These medications can cause side effects ranging from thrombocytopenia to drug-induced lupus. However, class I antiarrhythmics are not used in the treatment of angina and would not cause the side effects described in the question stem.
❌  Inhibition of beta-adrenergic receptors:
Incorrect: Beta-blockers can be used to treat angina by decreasing heart rate and contractility, which in turn reduces myocardial oxygen demand. Side effects include bradycardia, bronchospasm, and fatigue. However, it would be atypical for beta-blockers to cause the side effects described in the question stem. 
❌ Inhibition of phosphodiesterase-5:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of PDE-5 inhibitors, such as sildenafil. PDE-5 inhibitors can treat erectile dysfunction, pulmonary hypertension, and benign prostatic hyperplasia. Side effects include headaches, flushing, and dyspepsia. However, PDE-5 inhibitors are not involved in the treatment of stable angina and would not cause gum hypertrophy.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman visits the clinic for her annual health checkup. She states that she feels well at rest but has noticed chest discomfort with exertion. She denies dyspnea, orthopnea, cough, or syncope. Her medical history includes asthma and hypercholesterolemia. Her current medications include inhaled albuterol, inhaled corticosteroids, and atorvastatin. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years and drinks 1-2 beers daily. She does not use recreational drugs. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> of 97%. BMI is 30 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. The cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Resting ECG shows normal sinus rhythm without ST or T wave abnormalities. Exercise stress ECG shows ST depression of 1 mm in leads II, III, and avF with minimal exertion. She is initiated on aspirin, diltiazem, sublingual nitroglycerin tablets PRN, and counseled on smoking cessation. A coronary angiogram is scheduled for the next visit. Which of the following ECG changes can be expected given her new treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms and risk factors indicative of coronary artery disease. In the absence of resting ECG changes, noninvasive stress testing is the initial evaluation of choice. Cardiac stress testing that reveals ST depression with minimal exertion requires medical therapy and further evaluation with percutaneous coronary angiography.

Diltiazem is a potent coronary vasodilator that increases blood flow to vessels supplying normal and ischemic myocardium. In non-pacemaker tissue, class IV antiarrhythmics such as verapamil and diltiazem exert negative inotropic effects by inhibiting excitation-contraction coupling in the myocardium. This reduces the myocardial oxygen demand by acting as a negative inotrope, relieving angina.

The electrophysiological changes resulting from calcium channel blockade administration include prolongation of the effective refractory period of the AV node (pacemaker cardiomyocytes).
 

On an ECG, these electrophysiological changes manifest as a prolongation of the PR interval (>200ms). Thus the adverse effect of this medication includes AV block and sinus node depression. Consequently, medications like verapamil and diltiazem are contraindicated in patients with heart block and sick sinus syndrome.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Right axis deviation:
Incorrect: Right axis deviation is expected with conditions that involve right coronary pathology such as pulmonary hypertension, right ventricular hypertrophy, chronic lung disease, and pulmonary embolism. It is not anticipated with diltiazem administration.  
❌ QRS widening:
Incorrect: Wide QRS complexes often indicate a ventricular pathology and are commonly encountered in patients using a class Ia antiarrhythmic.  
❌ Inverted T waves:
Incorrect: Inverted T waves can be a benign variant or indicative of an underlying cardiovascular disease. Pathological causes of inverted t-waves include myocardial infarction, left ventricular strain patterns, and LBBB or RBBB.  
❌ Tall peaked T waves:
Incorrect: Tall peaked T waves can result from ischemic or non-ischemic insults to the myocardium. Ischemic etiologies include both the hyperacute and resolving phases of myocardial infarction, while nonischemic causes include hyperkalemia and left ventricular hypertrophy.  
✅ Prolongation of PR interval:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of retrosternal chest pain. The pain started 4 hours ago while playing soccer with his grandson. The pain radiates to his left arm and jaw and is not associated with breathing or positional change. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and erectile dysfunction. Current medications include insulin, enalapril, and sildenafil, and he reports taking all medications earlier this morning. He smokes a pack of cigarettes daily and drinks 3-4 beers on weekends. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 69/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg, and SaO2 is 95% on pulse oximetry. An electrocardiogram is shown below. Administration of which of the following medications should be avoided in this patient?  


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient with acute onset retrosternal chest pain for 4 hours and ECG findings of ST-segment elevation in the anterior chest leads is most likely suffering from anterior wall acute myocardial infarction. Nitroglycerin is contraindicated in this patient due to its adverse interaction with sildenafil, a phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor (part of his current medication regimen) which can precipitate severe hypotension.  

The primary mechanism of action of nitrates involves decreasing cardiac preload by venodilation and a minor decrease in afterload by vasodilation of arterial beds. This is achieved by promoting the conversion of guanosine triphosphate (GTP) to cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP), which causes smooth muscle relaxation via protein kinase G. Sildenafil, on the other hand, inhibits phosphodiesterase- 5, the enzyme necessary for the breakdown of cGMP. This results in the accumulation of cGMP, leading to excessive vasodilation and hypotension when used in combination with nitrates. If prescribed together, both drugs should be ingested at least 24-48 hours apart.  

Other contraindications to nitrates include bradycardia, right ventricular infarction (due to decreased preload), hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (due to increased outflow obstruction), and severe aortic stenosis. Common side effects include flushing, headache, orthostatic hypotension, and reflex tachycardia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin is an anti-inflammatory drug administered in all patients with acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction. Its early administration is associated with decreased cardiovascular mortality rate and decreased incidence of re-infarction and stroke. It has no interaction with any drugs the patient is currently on.  
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Metoprolol, a β1-antagonist, is administered in nearly all patients with acute STEMI to relieve chest pain, reduce arrhythmias, and reduce cardiac workload (thereby preserving infarcted myocardial cells); contraindications of use include patients with a STEMI who also have symptoms of heart failure (elevated JVD, crackles on lung auscultation, audible S3). Contraindications of beta-blockers include heart failure, bradycardia, and reactive airway disease.  
❌ Enoxaparin:
Incorrect: Enoxaparin, low molecular weight heparin, is indicated in ACS to prevent intraluminal clot extension, formation, and re-infarction. It should be avoided in patients with contraindicated anticoagulants (history of cerebral aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation, intracranial neoplasm, recent thromboembolic stroke).  
❌ Morphine:
Incorrect: Morphine is indicated in ACS for persistent chest pain. It provides analgesia and lowers the adrenergic drive, reducing vascular resistance and afterload on the heart and reducing infarct size. It is not contraindicated in this patient.  
✅ Nitroglycerin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old woman presents to the office for a routine visit. She is feeling well and is asymptomatic. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus. She takes metformin daily. Family history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and myocardial infarction in the patient’s father—review of systems is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Body mass index is 33 kg/m2. Physical examination is unremarkable. A lipid profile is obtained and the results are shown below. The patient is started on simvastatin. Which of the following best describes the effects of simvastatin on serum low-density lipoprotein, high-density lipoprotein, and triglyceride levels?  

Laboratory Value
Results
Total cholesterol
325 mg/dL
Low-density lipoproteins (LDL)
195 mg/dL
High-density lipoprotein (HDL)
35 mg/dL
Triglyceride (TG)
100 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient’s lipid profile exhibits elevated serum cholesterol and LDL levels. Statins, a class of lipid-lowering drugs, are the first-line agent in such cases since they significantly decrease LDL levels, increase HDL levels, and improve cardiovascular mortality.

Statins competitively inhibit the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase, which normally converts HMG-CoA to mevalonate (a cholesterol precursor). In turn, there is a decrease in hepatic cholesterol synthesis and an increase in LDL recycling via the up-regulation of LDL receptors on hepatocytes. The LDL receptors not only increase the uptake of LDL-cholesterol but also increase the uptake of VLDLs (the major carrier of TG) to a smaller extent, resulting in a moderate decrease in triglyceride levels. Furthermore, the liver increases its production of HDLs, which carry cholesterol back from the peripheral tissues to the liver.

The net effect is a significant reduction in LDL levels, a modest decrease in TG levels, and a modest increase in HDL levels.  

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Bile acid resins (e.g. cholestyramine) tend to decrease LDL cholesterol by preventing bile acid reabsorption in the intestine. Bile acid resins also slightly increase HDL and triglyceride levels. In contrast, this patient was prescribed a statin.   
❌ :
Incorrect: These changes are observed with fish oil and marine omega-3 fatty acids. Such medications decrease the transport of free fatty acids to the liver and inhibit the activity of TG-synthesizing enzymes. They also slightly increase LDL levels. In contrast, this patient was prescribed a statin.   
❌ :
Incorrect: A major reduction in TG is seen with the use of fibrates. Fibrates act by upregulating lipoprotein lipase, increasing the clearance of serum triglycerides. This class of medication also activates PPAR-α to induce HDL synthesis.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient was started on a statin. Statins increase, as opposed to decrease, serum HDL levels.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of chest pain, and a diagnosis of an anterior wall ST-elevation myocardial infarction is made. Cardiac catheterization is performed, and a drug-eluting stent is placed in the left anterior descending coronary artery. In addition to aspirin, an antiplatelet agent that blocks the ADP (P2Y12) receptors is added to reduce the risk of stent thrombosis. Which of the following is an example of this drug?
questions.solution:
This patient had an acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction and was treated with percutaneous coronary intervention with a drug-eluting stent. Long-term dual-antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and platelet ADP (P2Y12) receptor blocker (e.g., clopidogrel, prasugrel, ticagrelor (reversible), ticlopidine) is usually indicated, which significantly lowers the risk of stent thrombosis.

ADP is a platelet activator that binds to the P2Y12 receptor on platelets, induces gpIIb/IIIa expression at its surface, and facilitates platelet aggregation. Except for ticagrelor (reversible), ADP receptor inhibitors are metabolized by the liver and irreversibly bind and block ADP receptors to prevent platelet aggregation. A combination of aspirin and platelet ADP (P2Y12) receptor blocker is indicated in patients after percutaneous angioplasty, unstable angina, NSTEMI, and STEMI for secondary prophylaxis. Adverse effects include bleeding, dyspepsia, diarrhea, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), and rarely neutropenia (ticlopidine).  

Option Analysis

❌ Cilostazol:
Incorrect: Cilostazol is a phosphodiesterase three inhibitor that reverses the inhibition of platelet aggregation, vasodilation, and vascular smooth muscle cell proliferation. It is usually used to manage peripheral vascular disease (intermittent claudication). Although it can be used in patients with elective stent placement, it is contraindicated in this patient with a history of heart failure (due to increased risk of mortality).  
❌ Apixaban:
Incorrect: Apixaban is a direct factor Xa inhibitor that acts as an anticoagulant and is used to treat and prevent deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. Although it can be used in patients with a coronary stent (not first-line), it is not an antiplatelet drug.  
✅ Ticagrelor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Abciximab:
Incorrect: Abciximab is a glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor that prevents platelet aggregation. It is not routinely used in patients with percutaneous coronary intervention as it increases the risk of bleeding.  
❌ Dabigatran:
Incorrect: Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor that directly inhibits the activity of free and clot-associated thrombin. It is usually used to manage venous thromboembolism and atrial fibrillation. It does not affect the ADP receptor.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset of epigastric and chest pain accompanied by sweating for the past hour. The patient’s symptoms improved with aspirin and sublingual nitroglycerin administered by the paramedics. An ECG is shown below. Troponin levels are normal. She is started on conventional therapy for unstable angina. Upon re-evaluation, the patient’s chest pain is not improved, and another drug is administered to reduce the risk of coronary thrombosis. At the same time, she is scheduled for percutaneous coronary intervention later today. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this drug?
 

Reproduced from Flickr

choices.text: Relaxation of venous vascular smooth muscle cells via cGMP
Irreversible binding to and inhibition of the H+/K+ ATPase in parietal cells
Inhibition of the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin
Blockade of β1 adrenergic receptors in the heart
Prevent platelet cross-linking by binding to the glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with chest and epigastric pain, in combination with ECG findings of horizontal ST-segment depression, leads V3 to V6 and normal troponins, are consistent with the acute coronary syndrome (ACS) secondary to unstable angina. In addition to conventional therapy (aspirin, P2Y12 inhibitor, heparin, statin), a glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor (e.g., abciximab, eptifibatide, and tirofiban) is indicated to reduce the risk of coronary artery thrombosis.

Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors work by binding directly to the IIb/IIIa receptor on the platelet surface and preventing fibrinogen from cross-linking platelets together. There are three types of GP IIb/IIIa receptor blockers:
 
  • Monoclonal antibodies (e.g. abciximab, which is the Fab fragment of chimeric human-mouse monoclonal antibodies) 
  • Synthetic peptide antagonists (eg, eptifibatide) 
  • Synthetic nonpeptide antagonists (eg, tirofiban) 
These drugs are usually indicated in patients with unstable angina undergoing percutaneous coronary angioplasty whose pain is not resolved with conventional therapy. Major adverse effects include bleeding and thrombocytopenia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Relaxation of venous vascular smooth muscle cells via cGMP:
Incorrect: Nitrates act by causing venous smooth muscle relaxation (via cGMP), leading to a decrease in cardiac preload, which, in turn, causes a decrease in myocardial oxygen demand. It plays no role in the prevention of coronary thrombosis.  
❌ Irreversible binding to and inhibition of the H+/K+ ATPase in parietal cells:
Incorrect: Proton pump inhibitors (e.g. omeprazole) irreversibly bind to and inhibit H+/K+–ATPase in parietal cells and are usually used in the management of gastroesophageal reflux disease and peptic ulcer disease. It is not indicated in this patient.  
❌ Inhibition of the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin:
Incorrect: Fibrinolytic agents (e.g. alteplase) inhibit the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin and are usually indicated in patients with ACS due to ST-elevation myocardial infarction when percutaneous coronary intervention is unavailable. It is not indicated in this patient with ACS due to unstable angina or NSTEMI.  
❌ Blockade of β1 adrenergic receptors in the heart:
Incorrect: Cardioselective beta-blockers (e.g. metoprolol) block β1 adrenergic receptors on the cardiac, smooth muscles to reduce myocardial oxygen demand and risk of ventricular arrhythmias. It plays no role in the prevention of coronary thrombosis.  
✅ Prevent platelet cross-linking by binding to the glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A clinical trial is conducted where patients with a recent myocardial infarction treated with percutaneous coronary intervention are randomized to placebo or study medication. The survival percentage of both the groups is followed for a year with the following data demonstrated in the chart below. The differences between each curve were statistically significant. Which is the most likely study medication used in this trial?
questions.solution:
Medications that have been shown to improve long-term survival in patients after myocardial infarction (MI) include beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors, angiotensin II receptor blockers, and statins.  

Beta-blockers (e.g. metoprolol) are used following myocardial infarction to reduce myocardial oxygen demand by reducing AV nodal conductivity, slowing the heart rate, and reducing afterload. They have been shown to reduce short-term morbidity, improve long-term survival, and prevent reinfarction and cardiac arrests by 16%.  

Other indications for beta blockers include the treatment of supraventricular tachycardias (SVT)-- especially ventricular rate control for atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter.



Option Analysis

❌ Furosemide:
Incorrect: Furosemide is associated with an increased risk of all-cause mortality in patients with coronary artery disease without systolic heart failure or renal impairment.
❌ Digoxin:
Incorrect: Digoxin has been suggested to increase mortality risk in survivors of acute myocardial infarction in a dose-dependent relationship.
❌ Morphine:
Incorrect: Morphine has been associated with a higher risk of death in patients presenting with NSTEMI. No mortality benefit has been observed.
✅ Metoprolol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Amlodipine:
Incorrect: Amlodipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker that does not reduce post-myocardial infarction mortality.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to chest pain which started an hour ago while playing soccer with his grandchild. He describes a crushing pain that radiates down the left arm and is rated as eight on a ten-point scale. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, and erectile dysfunction. Current medications include atorvastatin, lisinopril, metformin, and sildenafil. Family history is noncontributory. The patient smokes one pack of cigarettes daily, drinks five to six beers on weekends, and does not use illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.2°F), pulse is 102/minute, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 150/89 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally, and cardiac examination shows no murmurs. A 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) is shown below. Which of the following medications, if administered, is most likely to result in serious complications in this patient? 


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with typical chest pain in combination with ECG findings of ST-elevation in anterior precordial leads is suggestive of ST-elevation myocardial (STEMI). Nitroglycerin administration should be avoided in this patient due to the risk of profound hypotension when given together with sildenafil, a phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) inhibitor.    

Nitrates are converted to nitric oxide, which promotes the conversion of guanosine triphosphate (GTP) to cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP). An increase in cGMP leads to vascular smooth muscle relaxation. PDE-5 is normally responsible for the breakdown of cGMP and is inhibited by PDE-5 inibitors (e.g. sildenafil). PDE-5 inhibition causes a decrease in the hydrolysis of cGMP in vascular smooth muscle cells. This results in the accumulation of cGMP, leading to excessive vasodilation and profound hypotension when used in combination with nitrates (which also cause accumulation of cGMP).    



Option Analysis

❌ Aspirin :
Incorrect: The antiplatelet effects of aspirin are significant in patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS). 325 mg aspirin should be administered as part of initial management in all patients with suspected myocardial infarction (MI). 
❌ Clopidogrel :
Incorrect: Patients with ACS should receive dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and another antiplatelet agent (e.g., clopidogrel, prasugrel, ticagrelor) before primary percutaneous intervention (PCI) or fibrinolytic therapy. It can be safely administered to this patient. 
❌ Enoxaparin :
Incorrect: Enoxaparin, low molecular weight heparin, is indicated in ACS to prevent intraluminal clot extension, formation, and re-infarction. It should be avoided in patients with contraindication to anticoagulants (e.g., history of cerebral aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation, intracranial neoplasm) and used cautiously if any recent (within the past six months) thromboembolic stroke. 
❌ Fentanyl :
Incorrect: Adequate analgesia is important for managing pain and anxiety (with resultant tachycardia). Fentanyl can be safely administered to this patient. 
✅ Nitroglycerin :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction. The patient undergoes a percutaneous coronary artery angiography with stent placement in the left anterior descending artery. Three days later, the patient reports new-onset chest pain relieved by leaning forward and worsens with deep inspiration. The patient has no shortness of breath, lightheadedness or abdominal pain. Temperature is 37.2C (98.9F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a friction rub over the left sternal border. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The patient is treated with aspirin, resulting in significant relief of his symptoms. Which of the following describes the mechanism of action of this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of pleuritic chest pain following a recent myocardial infarction is suggestive of post-myocardial infarction pericarditis. Although most patients improve with supportive measures, patients with persistent symptoms can be managed with aspirin and colchicine.  

Aspirin (acetylsalicylic acid) works by irreversibly inhibiting both COX-1 and COX-2 (via acetylation).  This is in contrast to reversible COX inhibitors (non-aspirin NSAIDs) which can be further subdivided into 2 groups: non-selective COX inhibitors (e.g. ibuprofen), and selective COX-2 inhibitors (e.g. celecoxib).  

Once absorbed, aspirin irreversibly inhibits COX-1 in platelets via covalent acetylation, decreasing the production of thromboxane A2–making it useful as an antiplatelet medication. Since aspirin irreversibly prevents the platelets from synthesizing new COX-1 enzymes, its effects persist until new platelets are produced. Ultimately, this is reflected in an increased bleeding time without affecting the prothrombin time (PT) or partial thromboplastin time (PTT). In addition, aspirin exerts additional antiinflammatory effects in the liver–resulting in decreased production of pro-inflammatory prostaglandin production.  



Option Analysis

✅ Irreversible inhibition of cyclooxygenase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Phosphodiesterase III inhibitor:
Incorrect: Phosphodiesterase inhibitors break down cAMP in platelets and promote platelet aggregation. Phosphodiesterase inhibitors such as cilostazol and dipyridamole are antiplatelet agents used in the treatment of claudication, stroke prophylaxis and stable angina. They are not effective in the management of post-myocardial infarction pericarditis.
❌ Vitamin K epoxide reductase inhibitor:
Incorrect: Warfarin serves as a vitamin K epoxide reductase inhibitor used for chronic anticoagulation. It is not used to relieve chest pain associated with post-myocardial infarction pericarditis.
❌ Reversible inhibition of cyclooxygenase:
Incorrect: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as diclofenac and ibuprofen are reversible cyclooxygenase inhibitors. 
❌ Xanthine oxidase inhibitor:
Incorrect: Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor and used in the management of chronic gout. It does not relieve chest pain associated with post-myocardial infarction pericarditis.
